title: EyeBench: A Call for More Rigorous Evaluation of Retinal Image Enhancement
author: Wenhui Zhu (Arizona State University), Xuanzhao Dong (Arizona State University), Xin Li (Arizona State University), Yujian Xiong (Arizona State University), Xiwen Chen (Clemson University), Peijie Qiu (Washington University in St. Louis), Vamsi Krishna Vasa (Arizona State University), Oana Dumitrascu (Mayo Clinic)
relevance_why: The methods for image quality evaluation could inspire similar frameworks for audio quality enhancement, where rigorous evaluation benchmarks are also critically needed.
background: This research assesses the quality of retinal images enhanced by generative models, aiming to align enhancements with clinical needs and establish a robust evaluation standard.
contribution: This paper introduces EyeBench to solve challenges in evaluating retinal image enhancement, achieving a multi-dimensional assessment framework that correlates with clinical preferences.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods focused primarily on single evaluation metrics like PSNR and SSIM to evaluate image quality.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves on prior efforts by incorporating both No-Reference and Full-Reference quality assessments, alongside clinically relevant downstream tasks.

key_innovation: Utilizes expert-annotated protocols and establishes a comprehensive benchmark involving multiple evaluation dimensions that align with clinical applications.
real_world_impact: Enhances the reliability of retinal image analysis tools in medical settings, potentially improving diagnostic accuracy by facilitating better model evaluations. However, no immediate real-world impact is evident yet.
limitations: No limitations were explicitly mentioned by the authors.

new_terms.No-Reference Evaluation: **No-Reference Evaluation** refers to methods of assessing image quality without the need for a ground-truth reference image.
new_terms.Full-Reference Evaluation: **Full-Reference Evaluation** involves comparing the enhanced image to a high-quality reference image to assess improvement in quality.
